Comment: \>But $150 billion in federal savings is hardly small change.  I hate to say it, but comparatively speaking, it IS. It's less than 10% of our annual budget deficit....and it's less than .5% of our national debt.  \>On Ukraine, through his hyperbole and bluster, Trump has changed perceptions of the war in a way that could make a difficult peace deal easier for all sides to swallow.  Maybe....but no deal has been made and there is no current movement towards one.  \>On the border, he can boast that illegal crossings have been reduced by 95 per cent.  Absolutely! And the President should be congratulated by every American who cares about border security. Then Dems said it couldn't be done....Trump did it in less than 2 months. The only downside is that Americans have short memories and as other problems become more acute, Trump's historic border accomplishment will become old news. Problems that are solved no longer command the public's attention.  \>This week, on the North Lawn of the White House, the President‚Äôs press team put out a long row of signs, each featuring a criminal immigrant who has been arrested. A bizarre stunt, no doubt, but one that emphasised the President‚Äôs highly popular commitment to removing dangerous aliens.  Absolutely. Brilliant public relations! As the liberal media denounced it, they publicized his accomplishments in the process.  \>By declaring ‚Äòwar‚Äô on Harvard over its DEI policies, the administration can force all other higher educational institutions to undo DEI.  The right thing to do. Kudos to the President.  \>By threatening to annex Greenland and plunder its rare-earth minerals, Trump can ‚Äòdrill baby drill‚Äô across America with less resistance.  Nonsense. Trump's Greenland gambit had nothing whatsoever to do with the relative level of resistance to domestic energy production. The author is really reaching here. What the Greenland gambit DID succeed in doing was to alarm our allies in Europe and Canada that America suddenly has imperial ambitions that seem impervious to our alliances and international relations.  \>Liberation Day may go down as the moment the second Trump administration started to fall apart. Or it may prove to be another masterclass in madman brinkmanship.  Maybe. The jury is still out. But one thing business requires to operate and grow effectively is stability and certitude...and Trump has stripped that away from our corporate and business class. NO ONE can deny that Trump's tariffs have hurt the economy.  \>Opponents taunt him for having folded, yet emerging trade arrangements, such as the reportedly imminent deal with India, could end up being hugely advantageous to America.  "Could" is the operative word here. I'm rooting for him...but this is all still just conjecture.  \>Meanwhile, the White House can brag about the ‚Äò$5 trillion-plus in new investment‚Äô that nervous companies and countries have allegedly pledged to America, plus the billions his External Revenue Service is bringing in through tariffs, which Trump claims will be offset by beautiful tax cuts any day now.  "Pledges" are only pledges. It remains to be seen exactly how much of this "new investment" becomes reality. But one thing is certain, building factories take time.......and the likelihood of new investment helping Republican chances in 2026 is scant.  \>The bet‚Äôs already paying off. Trump, the revolutionary gambler, is playing poker with the highest stakes imaginable. And he‚Äôs yet to lose.  Other than the border and DEI (both significant accomplishments), he has yet to win.
Author: Vessarionovich
